content.text: CSS Specificity
What is Specificity?
If there are two or more CSS rules that point to the same element, the selector with the highest specificity will "win", and its style declaration will be applied to that HTML element.
content.html: If there are two or more CSS rules that point to the same element, the selector with the highest specificity will "win", and its style declaration will be applied to that HTML element.

content.text: Think of specificity as a hierarchy that determines which style declaration is ultimately applied to an element.
content.html: Think of specificity as a hierarchy that determines which style declaration is ultimately applied to an element.

content.text: Look at the following examples:

content.code_html:
<html>
<head>
  <style>
    p {color: red;}
  </style>
</head>
<body>

<p>Hello World!</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Now, look at example 2:

content.code_html:
<html>
<head>
  <style>
    .test {color: green;}
    p {color: red;}
  </style>
</head>
<body>

<p class="test">Hello World!</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Now, look at example 3:

content.code: Hello World!
content.code_html:
<html>
<head>
  <style>
    #demo {color: blue;}
    .test {color: green;}
    p {color: red;}
  </style>
</head>
<body>

<p id="demo" class="test">Hello World!</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Now, look at example 4:

content.code: Hello World!
content.code_html:
<html>
<head>
  <style>
    #demo {color: blue;}
    .test {color: green;}
    p {color: red;}
  </style>
</head>
<body>

<p id="demo" class="test" style="color: pink;">Hello World!</p>

</body>
</html>

content.text: Specificity Hierarchy
Every CSS selector has a position in the specificity hierarchy.
content.html: Every CSS selector has a position in the specificity hierarchy.

content.code_html:
Priority Example Description
Inline style <h1 style="color: pink;"> Highest priority, directly applied with the style attribute
Id selectors #navbar Second highest priority, identified by the unique id attribute of an element
Classes and pseudo-classes .test, :hover Third highest priority, targeted using class names
Attributes [type="text"] Low priority, applies to attributes
Elements and pseudo-elements  h1, ::before, ::after Lowest priority, applies to HTML elements and pseudo-elements

content.text: More Specificity Rules Examples
Equal specificity: the latest rule wins - If the same rule is written twice into the external style sheet, then the latest rule wins:
content.html: Equal specificity: the latest rule wins - If the same rule is written twice into the external style sheet, then the latest rule wins:

content.code_html:
h1 {background-color: yellow;}
h1 {background-color: red;}

content.text: ID selectors have a higher specificity than attribute selectors - Look at the following three code lines:
content.html: ID selectors have a higher specificity than attribute selectors - Look at the following three code lines:

content.code_html:
div#myDiv {background-color: green;}
#myDiv {background-color: yellow;}
div[id=myDiv] {background-color: blue;}

content.text: the first rule is more specific than the other two, and will therefore be applied.
content.html: the first rule is more specific than the other two, and will therefore be applied.

content.text: Contextual selectors are more specific than a single element selector - The embedded style sheet is closer to the element to be styled. So in the following situation
content.html: Contextual selectors are more specific than a single element selector - The embedded style sheet is closer to the element to be styled. So in the following situation

content.code_html:
/*From external CSS file:*/
#content h1 {background-color: red;}

/*In HTML file:*/
<style>
#content h1 {background-color: yellow;}
</style>

content.text: the last rule will be applied.
A class selector beats any number of element selectors - a class selector such as .intro beats h1, p, div, etc:
content.html: A class selector beats any number of element selectors - a class selector such as .intro beats h1, p, div, etc:

content.code_html:
.intro {background-color: yellow;}
h1 {background-color: red;}

content.text: The universal selector (*) and inherited values - The universal selector (*) and inherited values do not impact the specificity weight value:
content.html: The universal selector (*) and inherited values - The universal selector (*) and inherited values do not impact the specificity weight value:

content.code_html:
* {background-color: yellow;}
h1 {background-color: red;}

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Which of the following has the highest specificity?
content.html: Which of the following has the highest specificity?
